data.Author: Honza Kral <honza.kral@gmail.com>
data.message: RequestsHttpConnection class handling the actual http communication

data.body: Requiring requests==1.2.0 conflicts with other packages.  As a library, it should really be more tolerable of versions and not require a precise release.
data.title: Less Specificity on Dependencies

data.body:
The rationale behind this is pretty much the same as in #1:

Many people use Elasticsearch over unsecured networks that requires encryption and authentication.

Added support for using a SSL-based Thrift socket. Since thrift has no support for authentication in it self, I added the ability to set some default headers on the `RestRequest`s, which is on par with HTTP-like interface of the Elasticsearch Thrift services. This enables, but leaves authentication as an implementation detail in the Thrift server-side, as it likely should be.

I tried to put some consideration into the argument names, but I'm not 100% sure whether they should be prefixed with `thrift_` or not, so I left that in.

comments_data.body:
[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/228656/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/228656)

Coverage decreased (-0.52%) when pulling **4a8d7bd6254b27d34425e2744b7c105e72616754 on nkvoll:master** into **d7814d09f7eacc957be7fa6915ae484707970fae on elasticsearch:master**.

And yeah, regarding the coverage, getting integration tests for this might be difficult, and I couldn't find any other unit tests for the surrounding code. Maybe some of these things be tested using mocks where integration testing is difficult, I'm not sure.

I implemented the SSL support, not convinced we need the custom headers, if I see enough need I will merge it, otherwise I will refer people to subclassing the ThriftConnection class and providing their own logic there.

Thanks for the patch!

> > >   File "/home/envs/datacat/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/elasticsearch/connection/http.py", line 65, in perform_request

{u'operations': 1, u'id': 1380138337607}, u'merges': {u'total_time': u'0s', u'total_docs': 0, u'total_size_in_bytes': 0, u'total_size': u'0b', u'current_size': u'0b', u'current_size_in_bytes': 0, u'current_docs': 0, u'current': 0, u'total_time_in_millis': 0, u'total': 0}, u'flush': {u'total_time': u'0s', u'total_time_in_millis': 0, u'total': 0}, u'refresh': {u'total_time': u'5ms', u'relocating_node': None}, u'docs': {u'max_doc': 1, u'num_docs': 1, u'deleted_docs': 0}}, {u'index': {u'size_in_bytes': 2278, u'size': u'2.2kb'}, u'translog': {u'operations': 1, u'id': 1380138337607}, u'merges': {u'total_time': u'0s', u'total_docs': 0, u'total_size_in_bytes': 0, u'total_size': u'0b', u'current_size': u'0b', u'current_size_in_bytes': 0, u'current_docs': 0, u'current': 0, u'state': u'STARTED', u'routing': {u'node': u'tdZ0joDcS729FXPQFplz_g', u'index': u'contacts', u'primary': False, u'shard': 0, u'state': u'STARTED', u'relocating_node': None}, u'docs': {u'max_doc': 1, u'num_docs': 1, u'deleted_docs': 0}}]}, u'refresh': {u'total_time': u'9ms', u'total_time_in_millis': 9, u'total': 3}, u'flush': {u'total_time': u'0s', u'total_time_in_millis': 0, u'total': 0}}}, u'ok': True, u'_shards': {u'successful': 2, u'failed': 0, u'total': 2}}

Maybe I just did something wrong?  I didn't see any example in the docs yet of making a remote connection, I tried several ways / permutations of url without success.

Thanks

comments_data.body:
Since you can use different protocols you should not include the transport schema as part of the hostname. Also hosts parameter to Elasticsearch should be a list of nodes, not a string with one node address. For http auth just pass your information as `http_auth`. Your connection code should look like:

```
from elasticsearch import Elasticsearch
es = Elasticsearch(["BONSAI_HOST"], http_auth="user:secret")
```

Also please note that support for http_auth is only in master, not in the version on PYPI, the @ syntax for hostname should work in the meantime with the `requests` connection class:

```
from elasticsearch import Elasticsearch, RequestsHttpConnection
es = Elasticsearch(["user:secret@BONSAI_HOST"], connection_class=RequestsHttpConnection)
```

repo.description: Official Python low-level client for Elasticsearch.
repo.name: elasticsearch-py

data.body:
Auth using the RequestsHttpConnection was broken with requests since neither session.send() does not add the auth object/tuple to the request.

Tests have been added to verify this, but the exact code path chosen depends on the version of Requests. On newer versions (2.0.0 and above, released 2013-09-24), the session provides a hook for us to prepare the request, but on earlier versions (1.2.3 and below), we have to take care of adding the auth ourselves since we want to prepare the request first, before sending, and those earlier versions of Requests only provide us with Session.send(), which does both.

Additionally, the constructor did not accept a list (of length 2) with the username and password similar to the Urllib3Connection. This has been fixed and tests have been added.

data.body:
The elasticsearch delete_by_query API (http://www.elasticsearch.org/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/docs-delete-by-query.html) supports a lucene syntax query string via the q parameter.

This pull request adds support for that parameter to the delete_by_query function in elasticsearch-py
